content: In the notion of (n,k)(n, k)(n,k)-category in higher category theory, what are nnn and kkk called? I am inclined to call nnn the dimension, but I'm not so sure about kkk.
"directed dimension"?

What do (∞,k)(\infty,k)(∞,k)-category theorists call the kkk?

(n,k)(n, k)(n,k)-categories are nnn-truncated (∞,k)(\infty,k)(∞,k)-categories, and I think in this case nnn is called the "truncation level", see e.g. section 11.3 of Cisinki et al's Formalization of Higher Categories.

I think they only deserve a name insofar as you treat them as properties of an (∞,∞)(\infty, \infty)(∞,∞)-category, i.e. "the least nnn such that XXX is nnn-truncated" and "the least kkk such that XXX has no non-invertible (k+1)(k+1)(k+1)-cells"

But when just saying "XXX is an (n,k)(n,k)(n,k)-category" it does not seem appropriate to call them something like "dimensions" because every (n,k)(n,k)(n,k)-category is also an (m,j)(m,j)(m,j)-category for all m≥nm \geq nm≥n and m≥j≥km \geq j \geq km≥j≥k.
Which is not how "dimension" behaves—n-dimensional Euclidean space is not also (n+1)-dimensional Euclidean space
Maybe you can say that nnn is a truncation upper bound and kkk is a direction upper bound
And then the least such upper bounds may be called truncation level and direction level?
I would leave the word "dimension" for geometric, not homotopy-theoretic contexts
@Amar Hadzihasanovic but one doesn't have to take the terminology to mean an infinity-infinity category with extra properties :thinking:
I am struggling to parse your sentence
I am not in the habit of thinking of a 1-category = (1,1)-category as a special case of an (∞,∞)(\infty,\infty)(∞,∞)-category.

In particular this claim doesn't type-check for the use of the term that doesn't have cells above dimension n:

every (n,k)(n,k)(n,k)-category is also an (m,j)(m,j)(m,j)-category for all m≥nm \geq nm≥n and m≥j≥km \geq j \geq km≥j≥k.
The term (∞,n)(\infty, n)(∞,n)-category or (n,k)(n, k)(n,k)-category is used in higher category theory to refer to the model-independent notion
So I would say that what does not typecheck is speaking of "not having cells above dimension nnn" in the same sentence as (n,k)(n, k)(n,k)-category, as that can only happen within a particular model
"Categories" are a particular model of (1,1)(1, 1)(1,1)-categories that does not have any cells in dimension > 1
They are not the same concept as (1,1)(1, 1)(1,1)-categories
For example, simplicial sets satisfying the Segal condition are also a model of (1,1)(1, 1)(1,1)-categories but they have nnn-cells in every nnn

Certainly the term nnn-category is used (for n≤4n \leq 4n≤4) to refer to a concrete concept. I find it unintuitive to imagine that (n,k)(n, k)(n,k)-categories should not be special cases of nnn-categories.
And I would use "dimension" to refer to the nnn in "nnn-category".
"Directed dimension" sounds like a reasonably clear name for kkk ...
(Although, (0,1)(0,1)(0,1)-categories are not really a special case of 000-categories.)

Nathanael Arkor said:

I find it unintuitive to imagine that (n,k)(n, k)(n,k)-categories should not be special cases of nnn-categories.

Though this does seem to depend on the definition: e.g. John and Mike introduce the term in Lectures on n-Categories and Cohomology informally as a special case of nnn-categories, but then define it to be a special case of ∞\infty∞-categories. As James points out, these don't coincide for all nnn and kkk.
I think the situation for nnn-category is not at all so clear even for low nnn (for n=3n=3n=3, should it refer to strict 3-categories, which are not even models of all (3,3)-categories?)
The current standard in higher category theory/homotopy theory with (∞,n)(\infty, n)(∞,n) being "model-independent" is a huge improvement in comparison, IMHO
Then as usual in these matters, if one could redo the whole terminology from scratch lots of problems could be avoided, but I believe that this is the state of the matter
I.e. nnn-category is simply not a synonym for (n,n)(n,n)(n,n)-category in practice...
2-category almost universally refers to strict 2-categories
But bicategories are also a model of (2,2)-categories
Not to mention the well-known problem of ∞\infty∞-category having been hijacked by Lurie and now being almost universally shorthand for the model-independent notion of (∞,1)(\infty, 1)(∞,1)-category
I believe the whole shift to the (n,k)(n, k)(n,k)-terminology has been caused precisely by the mess of the use of nnn-category to refer to particular incomplete models
What do you mean by "incomplete"?
I guess it's the wrong word, "non-universal" is better (I mean "not surjective on all intended models")
I am thinking specifically about 3-categories being used for strict 3-categories vs tricategories, in analogy with 2-category vs bicategory
Even though strict 3-categories are non-universal in this sense
I suppose I don't find it much of a pain to have to prefix "weak".
Weak is also about models.
Doesn't make sense to say that an (n,k)(n, k)(n,k)-category is weak or strict, a model is weak or strict
You can say that an (n,k)(n, k)(n,k)-category has the type of a strict nnn-category, sure
I mean with regards to the use of "nnn-category" to refer to a "strict nnn-category".

2-categories are already a pain when it comes to "weak" or "strict". You can decide whether 1. the object 2-groupoid is a set or 1-truncated or untruncated, and 2. the hom-groupoids are each sets or not. That's when people can start talking about "globally strict" and "locally strict" 2-categories, but nobody really does so. The combinatorics of weak and strict increases exponentially with increasing direction level nnn.

I am just saying that there is a kind of standard which has formed, and it is “(∞,n)(\infty, n)(∞,n)-category (or (n,k)(n, k)(n,k)-category) is model-independent, so it is a type error to attribute to it model-dependent properties”; I think this is not a very hard hygiene to follow, so I do not understand the opposition
According to this standard saying “every (n,k)(n, k)(n,k)-category is also an (m,j)(m, j)(m,j)-category for m≥nm \geq nm≥n and m≥j≥km \geq j \geq km≥j≥k” is simply correct
And it is completely irrelevant that there are models of (n,k)(n, k)(n,k)-categories that do not have cells in dimension higher than nnn

Morgan Rogers (he/him) said:

In particular this claim doesn't type-check for the use of the term that doesn't have cells above dimension n:

every (n,k)(n,k)(n,k)-category is also an (m,j)(m,j)(m,j)-category for all m≥nm \geq nm≥n and m≥j≥km \geq j \geq km≥j≥k.

Is a poset (by the usual definition using binary logical predicates) a category?

Madeleine Birchfield said:

2-categories are already a pain when it comes to "weak" or strict. You can decide whether 1. the object 2-groupoid is a set or 1-truncated or untruncated, and 2. the hom-groupoids are each sets or not. That's when people can start talking about "globally strict" and "locally strict" 2-categories, but nobody really does so. The combinatorics of weak and strict increases exponentially with increasing direction level nnn.

In classical category theory, the "object 2-groupoid" is not a natural object to consider; this is a particularly homotopy-theoretic point of view. So I think it would be unreasonable to say that the classical notions of weakness in low-dimensional category theory are painful, because they are motivated by different perspectives.
Within a particular paper, of course, it is perfectly fine for someone to use (n,k)(n, k)(n,k)-category as a shorthand for (n+1)(n+1)(n+1)-coskeletal complete kkk-fold Segal space or whatever

Amar Hadzihasanovic said:

I am just saying that there is a kind of standard which has formed, and it is “(∞,n)(\infty, n)(∞,n)-category (or (n,k)(n, k)(n,k)-category) is model-independent, so it is a type error to attribute to it model-dependent properties”; I think this is not a very hard hygiene to follow, so I do not understand the opposition

I accept your point. It is annoying that the terminology for low dimensional category theory and high dimensional category theory are not entirely compatible, but it is something we must live with now.

In any case, my original question was answered (namely, there doesn't appear to be standard terminology, but several reasonable suggestions were put forward), so I'll mark the topic as resolved. Thanks for everyone for the discussion!
Nathanael Arkor has marked this topic as resolved.
Yes, although I think that the shift to the (n,k)(n, k)(n,k) terminology has been exactly a way to create a new "namespace" to avoid confusion with low-dimensional category theory
Although that shift has proven relatively ineffective as higher category theorists start using the same notation as lower category theorists.
I mean, I guess some people do write things as (2,1)(2, 1)(2,1)-categories for strict 2-categories with invertible 2-cells, but what can you do
“Locally groupoidal" would work just fine
I already see people in the higher category literature writing "groupoid" for ∞\infty∞-groupoid and "category" for (∞,1)(\infty,1)(∞,1)-category.
(This is the kind of practice I was referring to in my previous message.)

So then a kkk-category is likely to mean an (∞,k)(\infty,k)(∞,k)-category, and an (n,k)(n,k)(n,k)-category in their language is just an nnn-truncated kkk-category.

The situation remains though, regardless the natural number kkk currently has no standard vocabulary.

I think it's still standard practice to state something like "category means ∞\infty∞-category" in the preamble of an article, that is, omitting the ∞\infty∞ is just to not flood the notation with ∞\infty∞ symbols... I don't think it's exactly the same problem
I'd compare it more with the way people say "space" or "topological space" to mean "compactly generated Hausdorff space" or "ring" to mean "Noetherian commutative ring" or other such examples

Like, from the point of view of a homotopy theorist it arguably serves the same purpose of "making things nicer", as from that point of view 1-categories have bad quotients etc. so even if you only care about categories you should treat them as ∞\infty∞-categories...

Is it reasonable to take away from this discussion that (n,n)(n, n)(n,n)-categories really are not the same as weak nnn-categories, from the perspective of weak nnn-category theory rather than (∞,n)(\infty, n)(∞,n)-category theory? Presumably the appropriate notion of equivalence of (n,n)(n, n)(n,n)-categories is weaker than that of weak nnn-categories? (E.g. a (0,0)(0, 0)(0,0)-category contains much more data than a set, even if it is homotopically equivalent to a set.)
Perhaps a slightly more concrete question: for any model of (2,2)(2, 2)(2,2)-categories, should there be a tricategory of (2,2)(2, 2)(2,2)-categories triequivalent to the tricategory of bicategories?

A model of (n,k)-categories also needs to model the notion of equivalence, which will not be the same as the "external" notion of equivalence (the analogy is: when topological spaces are used as a model for homotopy types, the model of equivalence is weak equivalence and not homeomorphism)
I think if you see it with the analogy of topological spaces vs homotopy types it's quite enlightening

Like, your question would be analogous to: is there a topological space whose points are small homotopy 2-types and is weakly equivalent to the 3-type of small 2-types? I think the part about the points does not quite typecheck (I mean, you can ask it but it is not very meaningful)

What I'm trying to say is, it is not entirely meaningless but seems wrong to "feed back" the model-independent things into a specific model, to speak of something like "the tricategory of (2,2)-categories" in the same way as it feels wrong to speak of a "topological space of homotopy 2-types"

Thanks, I think this makes sense. In that case, I feel the way the [[(n,r)-category]] nLab article is written is somewhat misleading (e.g. in saying that "an (n,n)(n, n)(n,n)-category is simply an nnn-category"), because it indicates that it is reasonable to directly compare the two notions.
I think the nLab does choose to use "n-category" in the sense that I am attributing to "(n, n)-category", and is mostly consistent about it; but in practice this seems to lead to confusion...

On any page about classical category theory concepts, "category" refers to the traditional set-theoretic definition, and not to (1, 1)-categories, and "2-category" refers to the notion of bicategory, rather than (2, 2)-categories.
My impression is that it is primarily on the pages specifically about higher category theory that the convention of n-category = (n, n)-category may be in use.
Furthermore, if "n-category = (n, n)-category", then what does one call the non-homotopical variants? "Algebraic n-categories"?

Nathanael Arkor said:

On any page about classical category theory concepts, "category" refers to the traditional set-theoretic definition, and not to (1, 1)-categories, and "2-category" refers to the notion of bicategory, rather than (2, 2)-categories.

Hmm... why do you say that? Certainly pages about definitions of category refer to specific models, but I feel like a randomly chosen page about some categorical concept could be interpreted just as well in any model for 1-categories, and similarly for 2-categories.

Nathanael Arkor said:

Furthermore, if "n-category = (n, n)-category", then what does one call the non-homotopical variants? "Algebraic n-categories"?

I thought the claim was that both are "model-independent" concepts, hence neither intrinsically homotopical nor algebraic.

Mike Shulman said:

Nathanael Arkor said:

On any page about classical category theory concepts, "category" refers to the traditional set-theoretic definition, and not to (1, 1)-categories, and "2-category" refers to the notion of bicategory, rather than (2, 2)-categories.

Hmm... why do you say that? Certainly pages about definitions of category refer to specific models, but I feel like a randomly chosen page about some categorical concept could be interpreted just as well in any model for 1-categories, and similarly for 2-categories.

I may not be understanding the distinction appropriately, but on many pages about categories/functors, there are explicit references to collections of objects and morphisms, but I would have thought if we were talking about (1, 1)-categories, we would have to provide assignments for all nnn-morphisms, so that these definitions are not well-typed in that context? (E.g. [[full image]].)

Mike Shulman said:

Nathanael Arkor said:

Furthermore, if "n-category = (n, n)-category", then what does one call the non-homotopical variants? "Algebraic n-categories"?

I thought the claim was that both are "model-independent" concepts, hence neither intrinsically homotopical nor algebraic.

I may be emphasising the wrong aspect, then. What words can I use to distinguish between the notion of weak n-categories where there are only cells up to level n, and (n, n)-categories?

I think we only have a "classical algebraic" notion of weak nnn-categories for n=2,3n=2,3n=2,3 and arguably n=4n=4n=4 ... aside from that we would need to pick some generic globular model like the Batanin or Leinster model on the nnn-globe category to say that higher morphisms "don't exist".
